page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 285: Line 285:
However, information minister Anas el-Fiqqi, denied that Mubarak would resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister [[Ahmed Shafiq]] said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
However, information minister Anas el-Fiqqi, denied that Mubarak would resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister [[Ahmed Shafiq]] said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
â
{{quotebox|"...I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution..."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
 
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and had a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but was satisfied with what he had offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to the vice-president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref name=transfers/> As far as transfer of power was concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article was used to transfer powers if the president was "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and did not require his resignation.<ref name=transfers/> He also said he would request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted.<ref name=transfers/> Mubarak said he would stay in the country and was "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref name=transfers/>
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and had a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but was satisfied with what he had offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to the vice-president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref name=transfers/> As far as transfer of power was concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article was used to transfer powers if the president was "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and did not require his resignation.<ref name=transfers/> He also said he would request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted.<ref name=transfers/> Mubarak said he would stay in the country and was "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref name=transfers/>
Line 297: Line 296:
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
Shock that Mubarak did not step down resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' supporting Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from unhappiness with Mubarak's refusal to leave.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Shock that Mubarak did not step down resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' supporting Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from unhappiness with Mubarak's refusal to leave.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
  +
{{quotebox|"...I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution..."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-11-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 11 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage. State television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!-- is this precise? -->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>{{cite web|author=Lindsay Carroll|url=http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down |title=Egypt's Joy after Mubarak's Step Down | Demotix.com |publisher=Demotiximages.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> Major protests occurred in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fireâincluding RPGsâin which at least one protester<!-- need to add to total tally --> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" />
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-11-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 11 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage. State television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!-- is this precise? -->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>{{cite web|author=Lindsay Carroll|url=http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down |title=Egypt's Joy after Mubarak's Step Down | Demotix.com |publisher=Demotiximages.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> Major protests occurred in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fireâincluding RPGsâin which at least one protester<!-- need to add to total tally --> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" />
